statement:
The derivative of a real function, which has on a whole interval a value
$c$, vanishes in every point of this interval:
$$\frac{d}{dx}c \;=\; 0$$\
The converse theorem of this is also true. Ernst Lindelöf calls it the
*fundamental theorem of integral calculus* (in Finnish *integraalilaskun
peruslause*). It can be formulated as

**Theorem.** If a real function in continuous and its derivative
vanishes in all points of an interval, the value of this function does
not change on this interval.

*Proof.* We make the antithesis that there were on the interval two
distinct points $x_1$ and $x_2$ with $f(x_1) \neq f(x_2)$. Then the
mean-value theorem guarantees a point $\xi$ between $x_1$ and $x_2$ such
that $$f'(\xi) \;=\; \frac{f(x_1)\!-\!f(x_2)}{x_1\!-\!x_2},$$ which
value is distinct from zero. This is, however, impossible by the
assumption of the theorem. So the antithesis is wrong and the theorem .\
The contents of the theorem may be expressed also such that if two
functions have the same derivative on a whole interval, then the
difference of the functions is constant on this interval. Accordingly,
if $F$ is an antiderivative of a function $f$, then any other
antiderivative of $f$ has the form $x \mapsto F(x)\!+\!C$, where $C$ is
a constant.
